q_en: List the raw materials and quantities used for orders in June 2024? And organize it into the form of {raw materials: used quantity}.

steps.sql: SELECT id FROM orders WHERE created_at BETWEEN '2024-06-01' AND '2024-06-30';
steps.description: Retrieve the order IDs for orders created in June 2024

steps.sql: SELECT id FROM order_product WHERE order_id IN (10, 11, 12);
steps.description: Retrieve the order product IDs for the orders from Step1

steps.sql: SELECT id FROM cutting_tasks WHERE order_product_id IN (32, 33, 34);
steps.description: Retrieve the cutting task IDs for the order products from Step2

steps.sql: SELECT produced_wip_id FROM cutting_tasks WHERE id IN (32, 33, 34);
steps.description: Retrieve the produced WIP material IDs from the cutting tasks in Step3

steps.sql: SELECT origin_material_id, SUM(number) as total_quantity FROM wip_material WHERE wip_id IN (8, 10, 2) GROUP BY origin_material_id;
steps.description: Retrieve the original material IDs and quantities required for the WIP materials from Step4

steps.sql: SELECT name FROM materials WHERE id IN (1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13);
steps.description: Retrieve the names of the raw materials from Step5

steps.sql: SELECT m.name, wm.total_quantity FROM materials m JOIN (SELECT origin_material_id, SUM(number) as total_quantity FROM wip_material WHERE wip_id IN (8, 10, 2) GROUP BY origin_material_id) wm ON m.id = wm.origin_material_id;
steps.description: Organize the raw materials and their total used quantities into the form of {raw materials: used quantity}

response:
Sure thing! Let's take a look at the raw materials and quantities used for orders in June 2024. Here's a neat table to show you the details:

| Raw Material       | Used Quantity |
|--------------------|---------------|
| Cotton Fabric      | 0.75          |
| Wool               | 0.20          |
| Silk               | 0.10          |
| Leather            | 1.00          |
| Synthetic Fiber    | 0.80          |
| Denim Fabric       | 0.65          |
| Down               | 0.80          |

I hope this helps! If you have any more questions, feel free to ask. üòä
